text: Hey Sahil, all great. Had a full week and did not see the message earlier.
It is indeed an amazing place to be, especially when you can do and influence so much on the products you love to eat on a daily basis.
A typical day for me does not exist. And I am honest with that. What I would say my job is split is separate pillars.
All of which need your attention and a different skill.

I would say that I need to support my internal business partners with their requests for quantifying what a change of price, a change in the pack of biscuits, a different biscuit mix, variance and more, would mean to the business.
So, my first pillar is supporting the internal business partners. Whether that is a marketing manager, a sales manager and/or anyone else with an idea in the area of Chocolate.
My second pillar is the importance of reviewing, understanding, controlling and challenging bad decisions.
For this, I usually tend to revert to data and understand that as well as the market and see whether this is good decision but also what does it compare to in the market.

Then, as these are mostly the small stones that add up, I also need to look farther from today and even this year. I need to look at what we call as macros (instead of micros). Those big blocks that our strategy needs to be about.
In pladis for example we have a moto that is the cornerstone of our strategy. It is to make the world happy with every bite.

And although it sounds cheesy, it is embedded within the companies economics. People try to create more products, the company develops more and more different types of biscuits for example to address the different tastes of people and make them also affordable to everyone.
So, my third pillar is long-term strategy.
I would then go on and add smaller and smaller bits as well, but it's important to actually analyse some of the school skills I acquired that then amplified through exposure.
But before we move on to that, let me know how have you understood everything so far and let me know of any other questions. If they are many, number them so that I respond to all of them.
